file_metadata.title: Bioelectricity is a universal multifaced signaling cue in living organisms
file_metadata.abstract: <jats:p> The cellular electrical signals of living organisms were discovered more than a century ago and have been extensively investigated in the neuromuscular system. Neuronal depolarization and hyperpolarization are essential for our neuromuscular physiological and pathological functions. Bioelectricity is being recognized as an ancient, intrinsic, fundamental property of all living cells, and it is not limited to the neuromuscular system. Instead, emerging evidence supports a view of bioelectricity as an instructional signaling cue for fundamental cellular physiology, embryonic development, regeneration, and human diseases, including cancers. Here, we highlight the current understanding of bioelectricity and share our views on the challenges and perspectives. </jats:p>

chunks.text: The cellular electrical signals of living organisms, known as bioelectricity, are not limited to the neuromuscular system but are a fundamental property of all living cells, serving as an instructional signaling cue for cellular physiology, embryonic development, regeneration, and diseases like cancer.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity is a fundamental signaling cue in all living cells, influencing various physiological and pathological processes.

chunks.text: Bioelectricity, arising from uneven ion distribution across cell membranes, manifests at cellular, tissue, organ, and whole-body levels, playing a crucial role in processes like cell migration, proliferation, differentiation, and cancer metastasis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity's influence extends from the cellular level to the whole-body level, impacting various physiological processes.

chunks.text: Bioelectricity is essential for maintaining cell volume, shape, and migration through regulating ion channels, pumps, and solute carriers, influencing lamellipodial protrusion and cytoskeleton signaling.
chunks.topic: Bioelectricity in cell morphology and migration
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity regulates cell volume, shape, and migration by controlling ion transport and cytoskeletal dynamics.

chunks.text: Cellular bioelectric state and ion concentrations are critical for cell metabolism by directly affecting metabolic enzymes, solute carrier function, and interacting with metabolic redox and energy carrier pairs.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity influences cell metabolism through its effects on ion concentrations, enzyme activity, and redox balance.

chunks.text: Cell proliferation is linked to cell membrane potential, with less proliferative cells being hyperpolarized and proliferating cells depolarized; bioelectricity may control the cell cycle through ion flux and cyclin/cyclin-dependent kinases.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity regulates cell proliferation, with membrane potential correlating with proliferative state and influencing cell cycle progression.

chunks.text: Bioelectricity regulates cell differentiation in multiple cell types, with membrane potential playing an instructional role; stem cells can be induced to differentiate into specific tissues using electrical stimulation matching endogenous membrane potentials.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity plays an instructional role in cell differentiation, with membrane potential influencing cell fate and stem cell differentiation.

chunks.text: Bioelectric signaling is crucial in embryonic development, influencing organ shape, size, and identity; manipulating bioelectric states can induce ectopic organs, suggesting bioelectricity's instructional role in morphogenesis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity plays a crucial instructional role in embryonic development, influencing organogenesis and patterning.

chunks.text: Bioelectric signaling is essential for tissue homeostasis and regeneration, with electric currents and ion channels playing key roles in processes like limb and tail regeneration in various organisms.
chunks.section: Bioelectricity in Tissue Homeostasis and Regeneration
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signaling, involving electric currents and ion channels, is crucial for tissue homeostasis and regeneration.

chunks.text: Bioelectricity is involved in planarian regeneration, controlling the anterior-posterior axis patterning; altering bioelectric states can permanently change target morphology, suggesting a bioelectric memory separate from genetics.
chunks.section: Bioelectricity in Tissue Homeostasis and Regeneration
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity acts as a rewritable memory in planarian regeneration, controlling body axis patterning and exhibiting long-term effects.

chunks.text: Bioelectric signals can induce regeneration in non-regenerative conditions and are involved in various regenerative processes, including osteoarthritis regulation through chondrocyte activity.
chunks.section: Bioelectricity in Tissue Homeostasis and Regeneration
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signals can trigger regeneration in non-regenerative contexts and are involved in diverse regenerative processes, including osteoarthritis.

chunks.text: Cancer can be viewed as a failure of multicellularity, with bioelectric signaling impairments contributing to the loss of coordinated cell behavior; ion channels play a role in cancer initiation, progression, and metastasis.
chunks.section: Bioelectrical Malfunctions and Cancer: A Failure of Multicellularity
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signaling defects contribute to cancer by disrupting multicellular coordination, with ion channels playing a key role in cancer development.

chunks.text: Bioelectric signals can induce cancer and normalize tumors; cancer cells may depolarize membrane potential for uncontrolled proliferation, and bioelectric changes influence cell differentiation and cancer stem-like cell formation.
chunks.section: Bioelectrical Malfunctions and Cancer: A Failure of Multicellularity
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity can both induce and normalize tumors, with cancer cells manipulating bioelectric signals for proliferation and differentiation.

chunks.text: Bioelectricity is crucial for cancer metastasis through its regulation of cell migration and the tumor microenvironment; ion channel blockers and external electric fields may offer therapeutic strategies.
chunks.section: Bioelectrical Malfunctions and Cancer: A Failure of Multicellularity
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity plays a key role in cancer metastasis by regulating cell migration and the tumor microenvironment, offering potential therapeutic targets.

chunks.text: The misconception of bioelectricity's relevance only in neuroscience hinders its wider acceptance; integrating bioelectricity with biochemical and genetic research is crucial for understanding its role in morphogenesis and cancer.
chunks.chunk_summary: Overcoming the misconception of bioelectricity's limited scope and integrating it with other research areas are key challenges.

chunks.text: Bioelectric signals differ from biochemical signals by acting as overall body patterning instructions and exhibiting a complex relationship with gene products; bioelectric patterns impact morphogen proteins and downstream signaling pathways.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signals differ from biochemical signals in their role as global patterning instructions and their complex interplay with gene products and morphogens.

chunks.text: Bioelectricity interacts with mechanical transduction through mechanosensitive ion channels and extracellular matrix proteins, coordinating complex biological processes like stem cell differentiation and cancer.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity interacts with mechanical signals through mechanosensitive ion channels and extracellular matrix proteins, influencing processes like stem cell differentiation and cancer.

chunks.text: Limited experimental approaches, including the dynamic nature of bioelectricity and the lack of a 1:1 relationship with gene products, pose challenges; new tools like GEVIs, optogenetics, and chemogenetics offer promising avenues.
chunks.chunk_summary: Limited experimental approaches and the complex nature of bioelectricity pose challenges, but new tools offer promising solutions.

chunks.text: Extracellular vesicles (EVs) and tunneling nanotubes (TNTs) are emerging frontiers in cell biology related to bioelectricity, modulating cellular bioelectricity through ion channel distribution and facilitating intercellular communication.
chunks.chunk_summary: Extracellular vesicles and tunneling nanotubes represent new frontiers in bioelectricity research, influencing intercellular communication and bioelectric signaling.

chunks.text: Bioelectricity is a universal signaling modality regulating cell behavior, development, regeneration, and diseases; despite challenges, significant progress has been made, promising further advancements in various biomedical fields.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectricity's universal significance and recent progress promise further advancements in understanding its role in various biological processes and diseases.
